js_lightbox-initialized"><span class="magnifier js_lightbox lightbox"><svg class="svg-icon svg-zoom-in"><use xlink:href="#iconset-zoom-in"></use></svg></span><picture><img style="height: 449.5px; width: 800px; background: #000"></picture></span></div><figcaption class="caption">Say goodnight, Dany.</figcaption><figcaption class="below-caption">Photo:  Helen Sloan/HBO</figcaption></div></figure><p>Ask not for whom the game thrones; it thrones for thee. This weekend <em>Game of Thrones</em>, the television show that invented death, finally ends. Now you can move on, at least <a href="https://deadline.com/2016/09/game-of-thrones-george-rr-martin-possible-prequel-1201822475/" target="_blank" rel="noopener" onclick="window.ga('send', 'event', 'Embedded Url', 'External link', 'https://deadline.com/2016/09/game-of-thrones-george-rr-martin-possible-prequel-1201822475/', {metric25:1})">until the prequel starts</a>. What should you watch next to scratch that itch? It depends on what you’ll miss about <em>Thrones</em>.<br></p><p><em>Breaking Bad</em>, <em>Mr. Robot</em>, <em>House of Cards</em>, and <em>The Americans</em> create tension around double lives, secrets, and violence. <em>Six Feet Under</em> kills someone off every episode. <em>The Walking Dead</em> puts its characters through hell, then resurrects them for evil. <em>The Crown</em> dramatizes the pressures of royalty. <em>Orange Is the New Black</em> follows a huge ensemble cast and makes you empathize with the villains. <em>Jane the Virgin</em> (also about to end) pummels you two-handed with shocking revelations. You could get a <em>Thrones</em> fix with <em>Lost</em>, <em>Rome</em>, <em>Heroes</em>, <em>The Tudors</em>, <em>The Borgias</em>, <em>Westworld</em>, <em>Wolf Hall</em>, <em>The Last Kingdom</em>, <em>True Blood</em>, <em>American Gods</em>, <em>Outlander</em>, <em>Downton Abbey</em>, <em>Boardwalk Empire</em>, or <em>The Wire</em>. Here’s what the Lifehacker staff recommends you watch next, and why.</p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-SPLASHYMID_MOBILE ad-splashy-mid" data-ad-unit="SPLASHYMID_MOBILE" data-targeting="{"pos":"splashymid"}"></div><div class="instream-native-video instream-native-video--mobile instream-permalink"></div><h3>A.A. Newton, Contributor: <em>Deadwood</em></h3><p>Do you miss the intricate, profanity-riddled dialogue, overwhelming griminess, and semi-historically accurate political maneuvering of early GoT? Well, then <em>Deadwood</em> is for you. Based on real-life Deadwood, South Dakota—and the historical figures who lived there—the show follows Deadwood’s transformation from a ramshackle mining camp into an actual town. It’s got intrigue, violence, power struggles, and sex positions aplenty, as well as the kind of old-timey racism and misogyny that people love to defend for being historically accurate—just like <em>Game of Thrones</em>!</p><h3>Abu Zafar, Video Producer: <em>Medici: Masters of Florence</em></h3><p>You want more political intrigue and dynastic rivalries? Do you miss Rob Stark? Look no further than Netflix’s <em>Medici: Masters of Florence</em>. This historical drama is set in 15th century Florence, and follows the trials and tribulations of one of the wealthiest and most influential families in Renaissance Italy. The first season stars Richard Madden (Rob Stark) as the ruthless and effective head of the Medici clan, Cosimo de Medici. The second season focuses on the most famous of the Medicis, Lorenzo The Magnificent. The show does takes plenty of liberties with historical facts. But the true history of the Medicis is rife with murder, betrayal, politics, and forbidden love, all of which is present and accounted for in the show.</p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><h3>Virginia K. Smith, Managing Editor: <em>The Sopranos<br></em></h3><p>This is in no way related to <em>Game of Thrones</em>, but it’s never a bad time to re-watch <em>The Sopranos</em>. Especially if you watch it the way I do, which is to make a theme night every time you watch it. Have some red wine on deck, and plate of meats/olives/GABAGOOL or spaghetti and meatballs or an Italian sandwich, or any other Artie Buco-approved red sauce type meal. Shoving cured meats into your face while you watch Tony do the same is weirdly satisfying in a way I don’t care to examine or explain too closely.</p><h3>Claire Lower, Food Editor: <em>I Think You Should Leave</em></h3><p>Quit watching high-budget soap operas and just binge <em>I Think You Should Leave</em>, which is the most delightfully absurdist collection of sketches I have seen in a long time. I put it on whenever I need pure, silly escapism, neatly packaged in 16-minute episodes. I have watched it four times now. Episode five—the one with the skeleton song—is my favorite.</p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><h3>David Murphy, Tech Editor: <em>Chef’s Table </em>and <em>Nailed It</em></h3><p>I’m going to do a complete 180 and extract myself from the fantasy world for a bit. That means it’s time to catch back up on Netflix’s greatest show, <em>Chef’s Table</em>, or the new street food-based spinoff. I hope they show an elegant, slow-motion, 4K shot of someone pulling a hot dog out of a street cart’s basin of hot water—set to some lovely Mozart music, of course. </p><p>Who am I kidding, though. I’m going to binge-watch <em>Nailed It</em> season 3, because it brings me joy and Nicole Byer’s boundless enthusiasm (for Wes) is exactly what I need now that my entire <em>Game of Thones</em> all-star team is dead. Sigh.</p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-SPLASHYMID ad-splashy-mid" data-ad-unit="SPLASHYMID" data-targeting="{"pos":"splashymid"}"></div><div class="instream-native-video class="recent-video__PublishDate-sc-16lj1xi-3 cMiFFS">4/26/19 11:00AM</div></div></div><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><h3>Lisa Rowan, Finance Writer: <em>Killing Eve</em></h3><p>I never got into <em>Game of Thrones</em>, because I was too busy watching <em>The Americans</em>, <em>Orphan Black</em>, <em>Mr. Robot</em>, and just about every other show that required turning up the brightness on my TV. If you as well just want to leave your screen alone for a while, put on <em>Killing Eve</em>, the surprisingly funny spy-vs.-spy thriller staring Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer. Maybe the body count on GoT is higher, but I’m confident you’ll acclimate just fine. And with season 2 about to end, you have plenty of time to catch up.</p><h3><strong>Nick Douglas, Staff Writer: <em>Borgen</em> and <em>The Thick of It</em></strong></h3><p>Instead of watching <em>Thrones</em>, I read the books, because I’m an intellectual. And my favorite part was watching everyone jockey for position—my favorite characters were Varys and Littlefinger. I don’t need the sex or violence, I need more of that deft maneuvering.</p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><p>Which is exactly what you’ll get from the first few episodes of <em>Borgen</em>, the Danish counterpart to <em>The West Wing</em>. Like <em>West Wing</em>, the series settles into issues-of-the-week and family drama, but it begins with a Thronesian struggle for control of the Danish parliament, which runs on a multi-party system that you’ll want to look up on Wikipedia.</p><p>But if you don’t want to read captions, try <em>The Thick of It</em>, the UK predecessor to <em>Veep</em> that’s sharper, meaner, and full of people ruthlessly (albeit metaphorically) backstabbing each other to get ahead in government.</p><h3><strong>Meghan Walbert, Contributing Writer: <em>Peaky Blinders</em></strong></h3><p>I’m the one who wrote <a href="https://lifehacker.com/how-to-survive-the-final-season-of-game-of-thrones-if-y-1834007786" rel="nofollow" onclick="window.ga('send', 'event', 'Embedded Url', 'Internal link', 'https://lifehacker.com/how-to-survive-the-final-season-of-game-of-thrones-if-y-1834007786', {metric25:1})">“How to Survive the Final Season of Game of Thrones If You’re Not a Fan,”</a> so you probably don’t want my opinion. Instead, I asked a true GoT fan (my husband) and he promptly suggested another show I’ve never seen: <em>Peaky Blinders</em>. <a href="https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2442560/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1" target="_blank" rel="noopener" onclick="window.ga('send', 'event', 'Embedded Url', 'External link', 'https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2442560/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1', {metric25:1})">IMDb tells me</a> this is a “gangster family epic set in 1919 Birmingham, England, centered on a gang who sew razor blades in the peaks of their caps.” My husband describes its appeal this way: “Tons of twists and turns, it has the violence aspect of GoT that some people are really into, rollercoaster relationship stuff, it’s grimy and dirty, terrific accents.”</p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><h3>Heather Hass, Creative Producer: <strong><em>The Song of Ice and Fire </em>audiobooks</strong></h3><p>My recommendation is for the sentimental folks who aren’t ready to let go just yet. For those of us who are going into the last episode dragging our nails, pop in the audiobooks. The narration is great, and each of the five books is between 30-50 hours. Also, in the books you really get into each of the characters’ heads in a way that you can’t while watching. </p><p>In between listening, watch HBO’s behind-the-scenes of each episode. That should keep us busy, and if we can save it for an hour every Sunday night, we’d potentially stretch this out for years. </p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost"}" style=""></div><p class="ad-label-bottom"></p></div></div></div><p>After that, you can watch every movie any of the characters has ever been in. Daenerys: <em>Me Before You.</em> Sansa: <em>X-Men: Apocalypse.</em> The Hound: <em>Hot Fuzz.</em> Arya: <em>The Falling.</em> Cersei: <em>300.</em> Missandei: <em>Furious 7.</em> Jon Snow: <em>Testament of Youth.</em> Jorah: <em>Tomb Raider.</em> Tyrion: <em>X-Men: Days of Future Past.</em> Brienne: <em>The Force Awakens.</em> Gendry: <em>Skins.</em> Ned Stark: <em>Lord of the Rings.</em> Bran: <em>The Awakening</em>.</p><p>When you’ve got nothing GoT-related left to consume and it’s time to move on with your life, lie in your bed, stare at your ceiling and listen to <a href="https://marielleallschwangmusic.bandcamp.com/track/matterfreedom" target="_blank" rel="noopener" onclick="window.ga('send', 'event', 'Embedded Url', 'External link', 'https://marielleallschwangmusic.bandcamp.com/track/matterfreedom', {metric25:1})">this</a>.</p><h3><strong>Joel Kahn, Senior Video Producer: <em>Barry</em></strong></h3><p>If you need something to watch after GoT, why not the show that HBO itself places directly after it in their schedule? This is, of course, <em>Barry</em>, which (even though it is a 30-minute comedy set in L.A.) will satisfy your GoT cravings. To quote another Bill Hader character, <em>Barry</em> has EVERYTHING: Shocking deaths, blood-thirsty warlords, complex thoughts of good vs bad, and dark dry humor. Plus Henry Winkler!</p><div class="js_ad-mobile-dynamic  js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic movable-ad" style=""><div class="ad-unit ad-mobile" style=""><div class="ad-mobile-inner"><p class="ad-label proxima" style=""><small class="proxima">Advertisement</small></p><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST"
